Posts.Content: Aug 1, 2010 07:39AM mari55 wrote: I am sorry you have to join us.  I too have bone only mets.  If the mets stays in our bones we will have  a good prognosis. Still, it is hard for me to see so many young women dealing with the spread of this disease.  I know your issues are different than mine since you have a young family and lots of years you want to spend with them. There is a woman who checks in every year who has lived with this for 17 years.  Right now there is no "cure" but there is control.  I have experienced significant regression in only 6 months.  I work and go on with my life because that's what you have to do. This forum will help you understand  more about any treatment that is prescribed for you and will give you a link to many wonderful women on the same journey.  First, I recommend finding doctors you trust and can talk too.  Learn bout your mets - is it hormone sensitive.  This dictates your treatment. I echo Holly's recommendations to look into some of the support groups for young women with this dreaded disease.  I check into this forum daily because I need to know I'm not alone on this rocky road and sometimes even the closest friends and most supportive family just can't understand.  Sending you hugs Mari

Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2011 09:56AM mari55 wrote: If I were you I would go to be closer too her.  I work with the VA and most of my patients are WWII vets so they are 80+.  If I have learned anything from this group of individuals it is that quality of life is the most important factor to consider.  Treatment that robs them of their energy or their mobility will rob them of independence and at this age it is really hard to come back to even baseline. You need to discuss with your mother what she wants. You need to hear from her doctors what they expect to accomplish with treatment.  If treatment will help reduce pain it may be worth it, otherwise it may be best to consider other options including hospice or care at home.  Making the most of the life she has left is really important at this point.

Posts.Content: Jul 25, 2011 03:51PM mari55 wrote: I had stage 0 ( calcifications, non invasive, DCIS) in 1999, no lymph involvement, had a  mastectomy and  was told to go on with my life,  it wouldn't be back. Not true.  Unfortunately ,1% of us stage 0 will get mets.   Those nasty cells can get in the blood stream and travel.  I have even heard of women who have mets that proved to be from the breast and have never had a tumor in the breast.  I guess that is one reason as a stage IV woman I get angry when I hear people say that those of us with mets just didn't catch it early enough.  I could not have gotten it any earlier.  We HAVE to have a cure not just better recognition. Sorry you are joining us but you are welcome here and can find great information and support from these amazing women ( and men) Mari

Posts.Content: Nov 29, 2011 02:58PM mari55 wrote: Right after diagnosis my blood pressure went way up ( 180/105 once) because of the high calcium from the bone mets.  I even got floaters in my eyes and lower extremity edema.  I started checking my own blood pressure because my oncologist didn't seem concerned ( I don't think his nurses were telling him).  My PCP put me on some medication until my calcium levels decreased and my kidney function stablized.  It went down and I came off the medication- no problems since.  The AIs can increase BP as can NSAIDS like ibuprofen.  Interstingly beta blockers ( a type of BP med) is linked with lower incidence of BC . Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2011 03:35PM mari55 wrote: Hopefully your mother wil stay bone only.  I have been stable on tamoxifen for a year or so now.  I am also on xgeva but was on Zometa ( zolendrate) for almost two year.s My oncologist feels the xgevais better at preventing fractures and is switching all of his BC patients if insurance will allow.  For the past two years I have had PET/CT scans every three months so that he could evaluate for other organ involvement as well as look at my bone mets.  My tumor markers have remained high until last month even though my scans have shown no change so I think that is why we were doing the PET/CT every 3 months.  I will see him at the first of February wafter having lab only so unless I have some other symptoms or my tumor markers go up I will probably get to postpone the PET/CT for a few more months  I have had MRIs in the past becsue I do have spinal stenosis from a T8,9 compression fracture but it has been stable so unless I have new symptoms of the stenosis ( paralysis etc) I won't have another anytime soon.  I have had bone scans too but my mets show up better on the PET.  I think you find a lot different approaches to monitoring by our oncologists. With some of us  tumor markers are very accurate and with others they are not.   Some oncologists never measure TMs. Some are followed by MRIs, some by CT, some by bone or PET. Scans can be dictated by insurance as well, as some find that a PET is not routinely covered by their insurance.  Hope this helps Mari

Posts.Content: Feb 9, 2011 02:43PM mari55 wrote: I also have mets to the thoracic spine ( with compression fracture) and my right hip.  I had radiation to both.  I have some spinal stenosis ( narrowing in the area around the spinal cord) so they have to check me periodically to see if I will need surgical stabilization but frankly surgery to this area is risky if they have to go through the chest to repair it. So unless I face paralysis I am going to avoid it.   Luckily I have not had to face that. The stenosis is better and I have very little discomfort except from the kyphosis ( curvature of the spine)  that is a result of the compression fracture. I can relieve it by stretching so far.  My last PET showed no new cancer and no activity in the thoracic spine specifically.  I did have to have stabilization of my hip ( Jan 2010)  which did involve pins and a rod. that runs from my hip to my knee.  It was a much easier surgery than I thought it would be ( In on Monday and out on Wednesday). I am back to exercising and I work full time. I suffered from the unstable hip for about a month before I had it repaired and once I had the surgery wished I would have done it sooner.  Good luck Mari

Posts.Content: Aug 29, 2011 03:15PM mari55 wrote: It is harder to wean those last few mg because during the time we are on steroids our adrenal gland stops producing natural steroids and it can take a really long time and a very gradual taper to get it kick started again. You may even have to taper by 0.5 mg or less and continue at that dose for several weeks before lowering again.  If you have SEs go back up to the next level and then decrease slower.  It is a pain.  It is also possible that your adrenal gland won't kick in.  They can do lab to determine if you are producing cortisol ( our natural steroid )once you are down to the lowest level you can get too.  If it doesn't they may be able to switch to a steroid that is easier on you. Mari

Posts.Content: Oct 21, 2010 06:45PM mari55 wrote: They do make a fentanyl patch at 100mcg /hr.  Pharmacies don't like to keep the oxycontin inon hand because it is such an attractive street drug ( it can be crushed and heated like heroin or snorted like cocaine) and it makes them a target for robbery. No one needs to be in pain so we each have to find what works for us.  I have been on MS Contin in the past ( long acting morphine) but have been able to get by with lortab in the evening for the last few months.  I also use a device called alpha-stim.  It has small ear clips that  transmits alpha waves to help decrease pain and anxiety.  It works well.  I work at the VA as a nurse practitioner and we are seeing  alpha-stim work wonders for our vets with chronic pain, depression, PTSD and anxiety.  It is even covered by some insurance but runs around $500.00 for the device.

Posts.Content: Oct 18, 2011 12:53PM mari55 wrote: I agree with Coolbreeze about asking for the transfusion.  At the very least you should have your level checked in a week or so in case it gets within range.  I was 8.2 and they had me wait two weeks before checking again ( his number is , 8.0) and then it was 7.7 and I have never felt so bad in my life. Even after the transfusion it took several days for me to feel better  This last time I was 8.1 and he went ahead and ordered the transfusion and I felt great immediately.  I have decided against the Aranasp or epoetin because of the data that it might encourage tumor growth.  These drugs work on the kidneys to boost a hormone that stimulates red blood cell production and are best suited for those who have anemia secondary to renal insufficiency. If you kidneys are working you probably have enough of the hormone. Mari

Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2010 09:04AM mari55 wrote: It is rare but I have heard of it happening.  It was explained to me that possibly starting with something like DCIS it gets in the blood stream but burns itself out in the breast ( probably an over simplification) but travels to the bone.  I am so sorry to hear this is your friends situation.  She would need a biopsy to know for sure that the breast is the primary. It also will tell if the cancer is hormonally responsive or not, which is what determines therapy. There are now tests that can be run on the cells to determine the most likely source of cancer ( and the percentage of certainty).  In my case I had DCIS 10 yrs ago, had a mastectomy and told I was good to go.  it showed up in my spine and the biopsy confirmed it was from breast cancer even though I had no positive lymph involvement or invasive disease.  Give your friend our hugs.  She is lucky to have a good friend like yourself. Posts.Content: May 25, 2011 12:00AM mari55 wrote: I have neuropathy in my right foot and lower leg.  They really don't know why.  The area that is affected is consistent with L4.5 or S1 dermatomes- don't have cancer there. Have spinal stenosis at T9 but that is not hitting the spinal cord. Haven't been on chemo that causes neuropathy so I have learned to live with it.  It may be from previous radiation or from the hardware in my right hip. It is better than when it started last August.  I have had acupuncture- that has helped some.  I have been on neurontin ( gabapentin), but have been weaning myself down becasue of SEs and don't see an increase in symptoms.  There is some data on a supplement acetyl-L carnitine ( google it or PM me and I will find the citations) and even a few clinical studies are in place looking at it in chemo induced neuropathy.  I take it and not sure if it is the supplement or what, but the neuropathy has at least gotten tolerable ( When it started it was all the way up my leg  and hip and affecting bladder function).  Sometimes it is the stuff that comes with treatment of this disease that is the most frustrating on a daily basis.

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2011 02:50PM mari55 wrote: I have worked in pulmonology as an nurse practitioner.  As Fitz pointed out a biopsy on really small lesions are tricky and they prefer to watch such things for growth rather than go in with a needle and risk a pneumothorax.  Also, when the lesions are small it is difficult to get a good sample so the risk is greater than the possible benefit.  If the area not growing it is at the very least contained.  I think the most important thing is that they are watching it and yes this is the standard of care approach to these things. Mari

Posts.Content: Nov 10, 2011 12:13AM mari55 wrote: The anorexia- not wanting to eat and protein malnutrition can hinder recovery significantly. Low protein levels in the blood can also cause the ascites to be worse ( proteins hold fluid in the blood vessels and when protein levels drop  the fluid moves out into other spaces like the abdomen) You should talk to her MO about an appetite stimulant and nausea controlled as soon as possible.  If she can handle supplements like Ensure or Boost with concentrated calories. Adding a protein powder helps to get a lot of nutrients in a small amount of liquid.   Folks with low protein levels are also prone to pneumonia so getting her nutritional status up is very important.  Good luck Mari

Posts.Content: Dec 4, 2011 11:37AM mari55 wrote: Sadly  this disease is sneaky.  I have bone only ER+ BC diagnosed 2 yrs ago.  The usual treatment if it is only in the bone and ER+ is an antihormonal ( like femera, Arimedex, Tamoxifen...)  plus something to strengthen the bones ( zometa, xgeva and a few others).  What most of us call chemo is reserved for progression into other organs though I have read where some bone only BC has been treated with chemo right away. As far as a mastectomy, many oncologists will discourage it once we are stage IV, it depends a lot on your mother's general health, response to treatment and how she feels about it. Good luck to both of you Mari

Posts.Content: Oct 31, 2010 12:18PM mari55 wrote: I have only felt that from my onc at the beginning when he was encouraging me to go ahead and take disability.  I have been working full time since March. I had high blood pressure early on due to high calcium that freaked my kidneys out.  I would go in for zometa and it would be 185/115.  They wouldn't even tell the doctor.  I called his nurse and she just said it couldn't be the Zometa or femera.  I went right away to my PCP and she treated it.  My oncologist was a bit embarrassed when I told him what at happened. My oncologist has gotten to know me and he really is very good.  When I first went to him he called the radiologist and neurosurgeon directly to get me in the next day.  I guess, when they found DCIS in the left breast and I requested mastectomy and single stage reconstruction with implant my plastic surgeon , surgeon and oncologist had to defend this at the local cancer board because the board thought it was absurd since I had stage IV. My plastic surgeon is the one who told me this.  They won and I had the surgery with no problems last April. I sought a second opinion on my back ( I have a compression fracture at T9 and some increasing neuro symptoms) and I could tell that doctor saw stage IV and wrote me off.  The doctors that get to know me seem to get on board with the fact that I want aggressive treatment and wholistic treatment until I don't want it anymore.  I have reminded a few of them that no one knows when their time is up so as long as I am productive, working ( at home or at work) and not in horrible pain I want to be treated. I think the key is that we have to be our own advocates and speak up when we think we are being dismissed and if needed go to someone who is willing to work with us and for us.

Posts.Content: Jul 11, 2011 08:10PM mari55 wrote:  As the others have said, length of time will depend on if there is mets to to her organs and how much and if she has other health problems. It is so hard to estimate. As far as Medicare I agree with Chickadee they don't cover as much as you would think or for very long but they can help some. It is under Medicare part B and not every one opts to purchase this  Hospice is covered by Medicare and I am pretty sure it is under part A ( I work in the VA system so I have forgotten a lot of this) and  they can care for your mom in the home. They say 6 months estimated survival but I have a lung cancer patient who has been on for over a year.  On hospice however, you concede that you are dying and chemo, rads etc is not covered.  I am not sure how they view the antihormonals.  They do however, pay for all of the palliative care meds. I agree with talking to a home health agency (one with hospice may be able to give you the pros and cons of each).  Most oncologists have those they work with and you will need  a doctor's order to get an evaluation.  I also agree with Chickadee that being a caregiver is a tough job when it comes to the end of life.  Many of the assisted living and even skilled homes have improved  but you do have to visit often and ask lots of questions

Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2011 07:38PM mari55 wrote: Bed sores are caused by pressure when a person lies or sits to long in one place ( buttocks, spine, heels are the most common place).  Pressure results in lack of blood flow and the skin can go from just a red area that doesn't blanch well ( turn white when you add pressure ( stage 1) to an open sore ( stage two) to even worse ( multiple layers of skin erode away even to the bone).  You need to let her physician know what is going on.  If there are actual open areas she may need to go into the hospital or at the lest have home health nurses come to evaluate and treat her.  If it is only red areas make sure you can get your mom off of these areas every hour or so.  You can use vasoline to rub on reddened areas that look dry and are not open.  I hope this helps.  I am a nurse practitioner and you can PM me if you need too. Mari
Posts.Title: bed sore!!!!! marium mari55

Posts.Content: Nov 18, 2011 02:32AM mari55 wrote: It depends on the level of liver failure caused by the tumor.  Failure is reflected in her lab work. Physical symptoms of liver failure can include jaundice ( yellowing of the skin) , nausea, weight loss, abdominal swelling from fluid build up around the liver, and confusion from increasing ammonia levels.  I would ask her doctors how well her liver is functioning at this point and that should give you a little better idea.  Make sure they keep her comfortable Mari

Posts.Content: Nov 28, 2011 05:23PM mari55 wrote: Lots of different things. A 24 hour test is usually a more sensitive test on kidney function than a spot urine  test. A creatinine clearance which measures how much creatinine is filtered by the kidneys helps determine if the kidneys are having trouble. They look at how much is in the blood and how much goes through.  creatinine is a by-product of protein metabolism.  Sometimes they look at  specific proteins in the urine and the types that are present.  Sometimes they are looking for chemicals being excreted by the body through the kidneys.   Mari

Posts.Content: Apr 23, 2010 05:01PM mari55 wrote: I was diagnosed the first part of January with bone mets after 11 years post mastectomy for DCIS.I had been having hip problems for several months before diagnosis.  Scans found activity in my spine and right femur and they started radiation ( as well as zometa and femera).  The hip finally cracked and I had surgery to stabilize the bone.  It was amazing how fast I could get back to walking.  I had surgery on a Monday and went home on Wednesday.  My incision was only two inches long and they pinned the cracked area and also put a rod down my femur ( I do not want to know how they did it).  My oncologist was upset with himself for not sending me to the orthopedic surgeon sooner ( I went in to the ER).  I have been able to go back to work and while I still have a limp at times I am so much better.  I wish you the best

Posts.Content: Aug 17, 2010 03:51PM mari55 wrote: There is actually no codeine in oxycodone (Percocet) but if you have an allergy to codeine you might have an allergic reaction to oxycodone or hydrocodone ( lortab, vicodan). Unfortuneatley the only way to tell is to take it.  There are some other pain  medications such as Darvocet ( not very strong), Dilaudid ( hydromorphone ( very strong).  Long acting pain meds like MS Contin ( morphine) actually help without making you out of it so much.  When I was first diagnosed with bone mets I was on the MS Contin and tolerated it well.  I do not have any allergies to any of the pain meds thankfully. Now I take a couple of lortab at the end of the day.  Good luck.  I hope this helps some. Mari

Posts.Content: Apr 28, 2011 09:20PM mari55 wrote: Well, on the left side  where you have indicated the pain is occurring is; your stomach, spleen and intestines.  Lower left abdominal pain can be caused by diverticulitis. Any exercise stress?  Any urinary symptoms?  Urinary tract infections can cause abdominal pain. It isn't typical liver pain.  I would say if the pain gets worse or won't go away no matter what you do , if you have a fever, start vomiting or have bleeding or dark stools,  an ER visit is in order.   You might call the doctors office for the provider on call to ask them their opinion. I hope you feel better soon! Mari
